notesStmt.note: BBWW performed in Oskaloosa, Iowa, on October 3, 1896. According to reports of the Assessed Valuation of Railroad Property In The State of Iowa and articles from the Library of Congress-Chronicling America, "R. Law" is Robert R. Law (1847-unknown) who served as superintendent for several associated railroad systems from the 1870s through the 1880s, including the Chicago, Burlington, & Kansas City; the Burlington & Western; the Burlington & Northwestern; as well as the Union Pacific in Nebraska and the Montana Union out of Butte and Anaconda. See http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2010270504/1898-02-22/ed-1/seq-1/. See also http://publications.newberry.org/cbq/?p=189 for a letter October 6, 1896, from WFC to George B. Harris that mentions R. Law as an employee of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad (CB&Q) coming to inspect the lands for him. The "Park" is Yellowstone National Park.

div1.p: Here is some good news. R. Law3 is the supt of Burlington R.R. in Iowa. Mr Law is the supt who has opened up the coal fields and built roads to them for the Burlington in Missouri & Iowa4— And is realyreally the coal expert for the Burlington and the practiced rail road builder. Mr Law is coming out with me to look the coal fields5 over. And the most practical route to the Park6 from what I can learn they will soon push through our country. If they do you know what that means to our country. We leave Omaha Nov 6th

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Oskaloosa, Iowa, on October 3, 1896.
Note 2: The year is not inscribed by Cody but is 1896.

Note 3: "R. Law" is Robert R. Law (1847-unknown) who served as superintendent for several associated railroad systems in the 1870s and 1880s, including the Chicago, Burlington, & Kansas City; the Burlington & Western; the Burlington & Northwestern; as well as the Union Pacific in Nebraska and the Montana Union of Butte and Anaconda.
Note 4: Burlington and Missouri River Railroad Company.
Note 5: Most likely the coal fields were the Bearcreek Mines, located at Bearcreek, Montana, about eight miles southeast of Red Lodge, Montana.
